My investigations were primarily

1. <u>The Alimentary canal of Terebrululidae <\u>

that <s>[text?]<\s> they may find a place in
the Proceedings of the Royal Society 
My investigations were primarily 
made upon Rhynchonella psittacea -
for specimens of which I am indebted 
to Prof Edward Forbes which Dr Gray obligingly 
enabled me to compare them with 
Waldheimia flavescens & with Lingula.
1. <u>The Alimentary canal of Terebrululidae <\u>
Prof. Owen in both his earlier and 
his later memoirs on the anatomy 
of the Terebratulidae describes at length 
the manner in which the intestine 
as he states, terminates on the right 
side between the lobes of the mantle -
On the other hand, Mr. Hancock 
has declared himself unable to observe 
any such anal aperture & concludes from his 
own observations that the latter is
